circle.description: Circle is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

ellipse.description: Ellipse is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center points.

lens.description: Lens is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

omino.description: Omino is drawn based on the positive values positioned in an 2d array. Think Tetris pieces.

polygon.description: Polygon accepts an array of [x, y] coordinates and then draws lines connecting those points.  The path will start from the first point and end on the first point - closing the shape.

polygram.description: Polygram is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The first outer point of the shape will always be at top center. The cursor is then moved to the center point.  Skipping a vertex is what makes a polygram appear as intersecting lines, a vertexSkip of 1 will result in a regular polygon.

polyline.description: Polyline accepts an array of [x, y] coordinates and then draws lines connecting those points.  The path will start from the first point and end on the last.  points can be absolute or relative.

line.description: Line is drawn from starting points (sx & sy) to ending points (ex & ey). sx (starting x) & sy (starting y) will always be absolutely positioned, however with relative=true the ex and ey points can relative to sx & sy.

radialLines.description: RadialLines is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The first outer point of the shape will always be at top center. The cursor is then moved to the center point.

rect.description: Rect is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

regPolygon.description: RegPolygon is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The first outer point of the shape will always be at top center. The cursor is then moved to the center point.

sector.description: Sector is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

segment.description: Segment is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

square.description: Square is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

star.description: Star is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The first outer point of the shape will always be at top center. The cursor is then moved to the center point.

triangle.description: Triangle draws an equilateral triangle from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

arc.description: An Arc draws a segment of an ellipse.

cubic.description: Cubic is drawn from an sx and sy to an ex and ey with two control points (cx1+cy1 & cx2+cy2).

quad.description: Quad is drawn from an sx and sy to an ex and ey with one control points (cx & cy).

cross.description: Cross draws a cross shape from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

symX.description: SymX draws an X shape from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

symH.description: SymH draws an H shape from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

symI.description: SymI draws an I shape from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.intro: react-svg-path makes composing svg elements dead simple. Everything is a path. Have fun.
introduction.overview: Svg paths are a powerful tool for display all kinds of graphics including illustrations, icons, diagrams, and interactive data visualizations. However creating paths of even modest complexity usually requires a third part vector design tool and usually a hand off from designer to engineer along with a healthy dose of reducing assets to just the needed code.
introduction.overviewExample: Let's use the following as an example:
introduction.overviewExampleDescription: Visually it's just a circle and rectangle both centered in the svg and both outlined in red . Let's build this with standard svg.
introduction.addSvgRect: And now we add the rectangle
introduction.endSvg: This required a little math and some tinkering to get the dimensions and positions for the rect element, but overall it wasn't too bad.
introduction.buildWithRSP: Now Let's build it in react-svg-path
introduction.benefit: No tinkering, no math, and our code actually looks like a rectangle in a circle in an svg.
introduction.learnMore: Please read through the docs to see how this magic occurs and how you can use it create beautiful svg graphics in React blissfully.

demos.title: Demos
demos.intro: There are a lot of docs (always a work in progress), but here's some fun stuff made with react-svg-path.

centerEnd.title: centerEnd
centerEnd.intro: Some components in react-svg-path are guaranteed to end at their center points. This behavior can be turned off with centerEnd={false}. Nested components will still recieve the center x & y from parents.
centerEnd.circle: Circle still inherits center cx & cy

toComponent.title: Path.toComponent(props)
toComponent.description2: By returning .toComponent in our Triangle component we have now created a re-usable building block for ourselves

pathMerge.title: PathMerge
pathMerge.intro: While having composable components make designing complex svg withmultiple paths simple you may find a situation where a single path is more desirable. Why not do both with <PathMerge>?
pathMerge.compose: As shown previously we can compose our paths from multiple components
pathMerge.composeResult: The resulting output of the above looks like this
pathMerge.wrapIn: However we can wrap these components in <PathMerge>
pathMerge.wrapInResult: The resulting output is a single path where all path data has been combined.
pathMerge.nested: This is also possible with nested elements

markers.title: Markers
markers.intro: Markers can be added to end, middle, or start points of any path. Markers will "point" in the direction and angle of the path.
markers.arrow: Accepts any svg path attribute and a color prop
markers.triangle: Accepts any svg path attribute and a color prop
markers.line: Accepts any svg path attribute, a size prop, and a color prop
markers.square: Accepts any svg path attribute, a size prop, and a color prop

textPath.title: TextPath
textPath.intro: You can use the TextPath component to have text follow a specific path. The path can be made from any existing path components or your own.
textPath.withCircle: Here we've used a <Circle> component as the path. We also passed in an optional "id" value so we can reference the path later if we need to. Otherwise an id will be generated for you.
textPath.withQuad: Here we've used a <Quad> component as the path.
textPath.withCustomDescription: Here we've passed in our own path commands as the path.
textPath.exampleText: This is a thing.  There are many like it, but this one is mine.

nesting.title: Nesting Components
nesting.intro: react-svg-path allows you to nest the paths created by components - this is normally not possible in svg. The rendered output will still be separate paths. However when nesting components the child component will inherit a starting point at the parent's ending point. And you can do this endlessly!
nesting.centerPoints: Since all of our shape components start and end in the center nesting multiple will result in all of them sharing the same center points.
nesting.end: Adding one or more shapes or even <Text> to the end of any other shapes requires very little effort.
nesting.start: This can be reversed to use the parent starting point with the attach prop. The attach prop is set to `end` by default and can be set to `start`.
nesting.mix: And you can mix an match with multiple nested components
nesting.oxOy: You can alter an inherited value using ox (offset x) or oy (offset y).
nesting.noCxCy: no need for cx or cy
nesting.zeroCircle: center point with a zero size circle.  neat.
nesting.offsetX: offset x to center of line

svg.title: Svg
svg.intro: <Svg> acts mostly as a dumb container component. It takes in a width & height prop and passes that directly into a standard <svg> element. It also passes that width and height in the <svg> viewbox attribute as viewBox="0 0 width height". You are free to overwrite any attributes as needed by passing them into the component as props. You can also substitute a standard <svg> element.
svg.nestingDescription: Like most of the components in react-svg-path  <Svg> will pass its center point to its children as a starting, ending, or center point depending on the child component.
svg.responsiveDescription: Apply the "scale" prop to an <Svg> and it will scale down with the width of its parent container while preserving the content of the svg.
svg.notResponsiveExample: This first <Svg> is not using the "scale" prop.
svg.responsiveExample: This next <Svg> is using the "scale" prop.

distance.title: Distance
distance.intro: <Distance> acts mostly the same as &ltLine>. It takes in the same props (sx, sy, ex, ey, etc.).  The primary difference being how markers are applied and the fact that it will present a value in the middle if the line representing the distance value of the line.
distance.pixelsDefaultDescription: By default the distance value will be in pixels.  Passing in a color prop sets the color of both the line and the text.
distance.colorDescription: Passing in a color prop sets the color of both the line and the text.
distance.dottedDescription: Make a Distance line dotted by passing in the dotted prop
distance.textDescription: Add any value you like with the text prop
distance.markersDescription: Markers can be set at the end with markerEnd, start with markerStart, or both with markers. Acceptable values are `arrow`, `triangle`, `square`, and `line`
distance.scaleDescription: a scale can be presented by passing in scale & scaleUnit props

path.title: Path
path.intro:
This library wraps https://github.com/joemaddalone/path and further documentation can be found there. This library adds one additional rendering method to path.
Path.toComponent(props) returns a jsx function including attributes and props.
path.example: This path can be produced with:
path.pathCommandsIntro: For every svg path command there is an equivalent command available in path.
path.pathHelpers: And then for most of these is there is a semantically named helper method. Not required, but for complex paths it may be easier to read for those not familiar with path commmands.

arc.description: relative is optional, its default is false. Setting relative to true is equivalent to a

cCurve.description: relative is optional, its default is false. Setting relative to true is equivalent to c

horizontalTo.description: relative is optional, its default is false. Setting relative to true is equivalent to h

verticalTo.description: relative is optional, its default is false. Setting relative to true is equivalent to v

lineTo.description: relative is optional, its default is false. Setting relative to true is equivalent to l

moveTo.description: relative is optional, its default is false. Setting relative to true is equivalent to m

qCurve.description: relative is optional, its default is false. Setting relative to true is equivalent to q

sCurveTo.description: relative is optional, its default is false. Setting relative to true is equivalent to s

tCurveTo.description: relative is optional, its default is false. Setting relative to true is equivalent to t

down.description: Draw line from current position down by px

up.description: Draw line from current position up by px

left.description: Draw line from current position left by px

right.description: Draw line from current position right by px

close.description: Produces a "Z" command which draws a stright line back to the first point of the path.

ellipse.description: .ellipse is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

polygram.description: .polygram is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The first outer point of the shape will always be at top center. The cursor is then moved to the center point.  Skipping a vertex is what makes a polygram appear as intersecting lines, a vertexSkip of 1 will result in a regular polygon.

polyline.description: .polyline accepts an array of [x, y] coordinates and then draws lines connecting those points.  The path will start from the first point and end on the last.  points can be absolute or relative.

segment.description: .segment is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.

square.description: .square is drawn from center point (cx & cy). The cursor is then moved to the center point.
